--- title: "FOSS4Spectroscopy" description: "A major update. What's changed in a year?" date: "2023-08-15" categories: [FOSS] format: html --- Yesterday I pushed a major update to the [FOSS for Spectroscopy](https://bryanhanson.github.io/FOSS4Spectroscopy/) web site. It's been nearly a year, and there are a number of new entries. Remember that this is a lightly curated process; I have some scripts that automate the discovery of packages but there is still a considerable amount of manual inspection and decision making. Let's do a quick comparison of the results from November 2022 versus August 2023. ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: Back in November 2022 there were 246 packages; nearly a year later there are 287. @fig-venn gives an overview of the changes. ::: {.cell} ::: ![Venn diagram comparing the two sets of packages](Venn.png){#fig-venn width=75%} ## Package Language Development in spectroscopy is clearly actively occurring in the Python ecosystem; R has stalled (see @tbl-lang). Interpretation of this observation is challenging. A few thoughts: * One could claim that the R ecosystem for spectroscopy is mature and further development is naturally going to be limited. * The popularity of Python language must contribute significantly. * One motivation for people to write packages is to learn the language and the package delivery system. There's nothing wrong with these motivations, however this leads to packages that largely overlap in their features. ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {#tbl-lang .cell tbl-cap='Package language, 2022 vs 2023.'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
language Nov 2022 Aug 2023
Python 162 198
R 60 61
C++ 4 5
Java 4 4
Julia 4 5
C 2 2
Qt 2 2
C-shell 1 1
C# 1 2
Fortran 1 1
Go 1 1
html 1 1
JavaScript 1 2
TypeScript 1 1
XML 1 1
````` ::: ::: ## Package Focus @tbl-focus shows the change in package focus. * Most categories grew modestly. * As I look at it, all one-dimensional spectroscopic techniques produce collections of x,y data, namely spectra, and can thus be stored in a matrix. For two-dimensional techniques, one spectrum (or one wavelength) is a matrix, so a set of spectra is a stack of matrices (called an array in some languages). So a package needs a storage structure that accommodates this underlying structure. In terms of organization there's nothing different between a 1D NMR spectrum and a UV-Vis spectrum. ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {#tbl-focus .cell tbl-cap='Package focus, 2022 vs 2023.'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}

PES 1 2

````` ::: :::
